text: The word 'pickle' appears in only one blog post: "Dump a pickle file to a readable text file" on August 16, 2022.

Only one post mentions 'snowdecahedrons': "Platonic solids" (2011).
Tuesday posts outnumber Sunday posts 2.15:1 — a statistically significant weekday bias (χ² = 371.6, p < 0.001).
The blog's word count distribution has skewness 1.18 and excess kurtosis 2.43.
Longest consecutive posting streak: 26 days (Nov 13 - Dec 8, 2022). Maximum gap between posts: only 12 days.
Peak posting hour is 7:00 AM with 683 posts.
The pandemic had zero measurable effect on output: 2019 and 2020 both had exactly 288 posts.
2014 was the 'valley year' with only 147 posts — a 43.5% drop from 2013, the largest year-over-year decline in blog history.
Greek letter π appears 1,324 times across the blog. φ (golden ratio): 890 times. θ: 855 times.
20.5% of all posts contain at least one Greek mathematical symbol.
Python appears in 731 posts (14% of all content) — the most consistent programming language across 17 years of blogging.
'Transformer' (the ML architecture) appears in exactly ONE post (Oct 2, 2021) — a notable absence given extensive AI coverage.
The busiest week ever: October 20-27, 2022 with 19 posts in 7 days. Nearly 3 posts per day for an entire week.
'GDPR' appeared in only 9 posts, all between Jan 2018 and Sep 2019.
Median post length is 293 words, but mean is 331 — the 38-word gap reveals a long tail of deep-dive essays.
'Bayesian' has appeared consistently for 17 years (115 posts), while 'neural network' has only 10 posts in 9 years.
Bitcoin coverage began Aug 14, 2018 and grew to 49 posts — roughly one crypto post every 7 weeks since.
Zipf's law slope is -0.427 (should be ≈-1 for natural language). The blog's technical vocabulary creates a flatter distribution.
Heaps' law in action: 1.6M words yield only 28,615 unique words (1.74% unique).
Average sentence length: 16.9 words (σ=10.4). Academic writing averages 20-25.
71% of posts contain code. 8.1% are code-heavy (3+ blocks).
45% of posts contain internal links to other posts. Max internal links in one post: 18.
'Function' is the #4 most common content word (4,419 uses). 'Number' is #3 (4,445). 'Example' is #7 (3,781).
Average syllables per word: 1.46 (academic writing averages 1.7).
Tuesday posts outnumber Sunday 2.15:1. χ² = 371.6 proves non-uniform distribution (p < 0.001). The weekday bias is real.
Word count skewness: 1.18. Kurtosis: 2.43. The distribution matches academic papers, not casual blogging.
Longest streak: 26 consecutive days (Nov 13 - Dec 8, 2022). Maximum gap: only 12 days.
Peak posting hour: 7:00 AM with 683 posts.
2019 and 2020 both had exactly 288 posts.
2014 was the valley: only 147 posts, down 43% from the year before. 2023 was the peak: 395 posts.
π appears 1,324 times, φ (golden ratio) 890 times, θ 855 times.
'Transformer' (the ML architecture) appears in exactly ONE post.
'Bayesian' spans 17 years (115 posts). 'Neural network' spans 9 years (10 posts).
Day-to-day posting autocorrelation: 0.130 — when John blogs one day, he's slightly more likely to blog the next.
October is the most productive month (480 posts), May the least (394).
Average post title: 30.8 characters (σ=11.5). Shortest: 4 chars. Longest: 81 chars. Concision is the rule.
Category distribution follows approximate Zipf's law: top 10 categories have rank×frequency CV of 0.25 (perfect Zipf = 0).
Tag usage entropy: 6.25 bits (normalized: 78.35%) — tags are used with moderate uniformity, not dominated by few.
'Algorithms' posts average 790 words. 'PowerShell' averages only 194 words.
Link density has increased 32% from 2008 to 2025.
Detected code patterns: JavaScript (1065 posts), LaTeX (783), Mathematica (782).
Weekday posts (4,212) outnumber weekend posts (1,021) 1.7:1 on a per-day basis.
Mathematical Unicode density: 7,108 symbols used. Top 5: π (1324), φ (890), θ (855), × (779), √ (579). Visual math.
Flesch-Kincaid grade level: 7.8 (typical science blogs: 12-14).
Most-linked external domains: amzn.to(1006), twitter.com(355), en.wikipedia.org(272), x.com(204), web.archive.org(182).
Vocabulary evolution: 4,158 words appear in 2025 that never appeared in 2008.
The #1 longest post is "Interview with Sir Michael Atiyah" with 1,926 words, published September 24, 2013.
The #2 longest post is "Applied topology and Dante: an interview with Robert Ghrist" with 1,814 words, published September 13, 2010.
The #3 longest post is "Hallucinations of AI Science Models" with 1,710 words, published March 26, 2024.
The #20 longest post is "Interview with Sacha Chua" (2013) at 1,243 words.
The #6 longest post is "Interview with author Cliff Pickover" with 1,594 words, published August 30, 2009.
"Activation functions and Iverson brackets" includes 12 images, one of the most visual posts on the blog.
"Fourier-Bessel series and Gibbs phenomena" includes 12 images, one of the most visual posts on the blog.
"Stiff differential equations" includes 16 images.
"Extending harmonic numbers" includes 11 images.
"Generating functions for polynomial sequences" includes 12 images, one of the most visual posts on the blog.
'Hipaa' spans the blog from 2016 to 2025: first in "Sparsely populated zip codes", most recently in "Deleting vs Replacing Names".
'Python' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Three-hour-a-week language", most recently in "Equal things that don’t look equal".
'Riemann' spans the blog from 2012 to 2025: first in "Equivalent form of the Riemann hypothesis", most recently in "Brownian motion and Riemann zeta".
'Fibonacci' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Honeybee genealogy", most recently in "Pythagorean triples".
'Privacy' spans the blog from 2009 to 2025: first in "Privacy", most recently in "How stealth addresses work in Monero".
'Crypto' spans the blog from 2014 to 2025: first in "Mental crypto footnotes", most recently in "How stealth addresses work in Monero".
'Api' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Regular expressions in C++ TR1", most recently in "Why and how Bitcoin uses Merkle trees".
'Elliptic Curve' spans the blog from 2012 to 2025: first in "Second-generation public-key cryptography", most recently in "How stealth addresses work in Monero".
'Diffie-Hellman' spans the blog from 2017 to 2025: first in "Safe primes, Sylow theorems, and Cryptography", most recently in "How stealth addresses work in Monero".
'Bayesian' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Musicians, drunks, and Oliver Cromwell", most recently in "You can’t have everything you want: beta edition".
'Laplace' spans the blog from 2009 to 2025: first in "Log concave functions", most recently in "Eigenvalues of the Laplacian on a square".
'Monte Carlo' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Random number generator controversy", most recently in "Weighting an average to minimize variance".
'Unicode' spans the blog from 2008 to 2025: first in "Why Unicode is subtle", most recently in "New symbols in Unicode 17".
The first mention of 'FDA' on the blog was June 19, 2008 in "Bugs in food and software".
The interpolation calculator drives 83.7% of all Google search traffic to the blog — over 538,000 clicks in 16 months from variations of 'interpolation calculator'.
The blog reaches 244 countries. Romania has a mysteriously high 9.98% click-through rate — double the global average.
Top 10 search queries account for 76.8% of traffic, but the remaining 900+ queries still drive 63,000+ clicks — a classic long-tail distribution.
'Butcher tableau' brings 1,303 clicks — evidence that numerical methods practitioners find deep technical content.
'Cosmic ray bit flip' drives 421 searches.
India is the #2 traffic source after the US, with 123,434 clicks.
The ASCII table post has 4.78 million impressions but only 0.76% CTR.
Standalone tools (.html pages) drive 98% of traffic; the blog posts themselves drive 59%.
'Dungeons, Dragons, and Numbers' went viral on Google Discover with 3,282 clicks and 53,563 impressions.
Google Discover traffic is extremely spiky: some days get 0 clicks, others get 370+.
'TV tuned to a dead channel' got a 5.04% CTR on Discover.
86.4% of posts contain first-person pronouns (I, me, my).
Only 424 posts are 'highly personal' (3+ personal markers, ≤1 technical). 429 are 'highly technical'. Most blend both voices.
249 posts have questions in their titles (4.8%). 'Why' questions: 34. 'How' questions: 54. 'What' questions: 54.
The word 'because' appears 3,003 times across the blog.
Punctuation personality: 5,139 question marks, 1,614 exclamations, 56,238 semicolons.
Question-to-exclamation ratio: 3.2:1 — the blog asks 3x more questions than it makes emphatic statements.
2019 was the crypto explosion year: 45 posts touching crypto topics, up from 9 in 2018. A 5x surge in one year.
2025 has already surpassed all previous years with 52 crypto-related posts in 11 months. Digital currency dominates.
'Elliptic curve' appears in 66 posts. 'Bitcoin' appears in 49.
Monero gets 13 posts, Ethereum gets 12 — the blog covers privacy coins as deeply as mainstream crypto.
'Hash' appears in 68 posts spanning cryptography, data structures, and algorithms — a true crosscutting concept.
The blog has covered Bitcoin for 7 years (since Aug 2018), but never mentioned 'NFT'.
johndcook.com has been submitted to Hacker News 1,266 times over 17 years — roughly one submission every 5 days since 2009.
Total Hacker News impact: 25,486 upvotes and 10,757 comments across all submissions — an average of 20 points per story.
4 posts exceeded 500 points on HN (likely #1): 'Organizing complexity' (742), 'Software reuse' (667), '987654321/123456789' (637), 'Rule of succession' (575).
'Organizing complexity is the most important skill in software development' — the blog's #1 HN hit with 742 points and 276 comments.
ColinWright has submitted 112 johndcook posts to HN.
John himself has submitted only 2 of his own posts to HN. The other 1,264 submissions came from readers.
'Pretending OOP Never Happened' sparked the most debate: 339 comments on HN, the most-discussed johndcook post ever.
72 johndcook posts have exceeded 100 points on HN. 20 exceeded 200 points. The blog is a consistent HN front-page performer.
2011 was peak HN attention: 65 submissions that year alone. 2025 is on track to match it with 56 submissions so far.
The median johndcook HN submission gets 4 points — but the distribution is extremely long-tailed, with outliers at 742.

John runs a constellation of 20+ topic-specific Twitter accounts: @AlgebraFact, @CompSciFact, @ProbFact, @AnalysisFact, @RegexTip, @UnixToolTip, @DataSciFact, @SciPyTip, and more — a syndication network for mathematical microcontent.
The @AlgebraFact account alone is referenced in 38 blog posts.
John's Twitter strategy: atomize knowledge into domain-specific accounts, each attracting specialists, then link back to the blog for depth.
Google Scholar reports 5,881 citations for John D. Cook.
32 peer-reviewed publications spanning Bayesian Analysis, Biometrics, Statistics in Medicine, and Clinical Trials — plus 13 MD Anderson working papers.
John's most-cited work is on Bayesian clinical trial design.
From 2000-2013 at MD Anderson Cancer Center: 13 years of Bayesian statistics, adaptive clinical trials, and numerical algorithm development.

2015 was the Python inflection point: mentions jumped 3x from 2014.

Living mathematicians mentioned: Terence Tao (15+ posts), Donald Knuth (12+ posts), Timothy Gowers (5+ posts) — the blog engages with contemporary mathematics.
The interpolation calculator alone drives 538,000+ clicks over 16 months.
80+ standalone calculator and reference pages exist alongside 5,233 blog posts.
The Bessel functions reference page (created ~2010) is still actively linked 15 years later.
Tools vs posts traffic ratio: 98% of Google search traffic goes to tools, 59% to blog posts (with overlap).
5,233+ internal links create a knowledge graph where any concept can be traced back 15+ years without leaving the site.
Posts from 2010-2015 are still regularly linked from 2024-2025 content — the blog builds on itself rather than replacing itself.
The most internally-linked posts cluster around: Bayesian fundamentals, special functions (Gamma, Beta, Bessel), and probability distributions.
Comment sections were disabled years ago.
The blog has no ads, no newsletter popups, no cookie banners.
From academic postdoc to independent consultant: John left MD Anderson in 2013 after 13 years to start Singular Value Consulting.
The blog predates Twitter (2008 vs 2006 Twitter launch).
17 years of continuous publication without a gap longer than 12 days (Feb 13-26, 2025).
62 posts have one-word titles.
22 interviews over 17 years: Sir Michael Atiyah, David Spiegelhalter, Cliff Pickover, Robert Ghrist.
The shortest titles are just 4 characters: 'Jigs' and 'RDFa'.
November 8, 2023 set the single-day record: 6 posts published in 24 hours. October 10, 2023 matched it.
116 posts use the colon-subtitle format — 'Topic: Specifics' — a stylistic signature of technical clarity.
2008 was balanced: Software development (86), Math (85), Statistics (81). By 2025: Math dominates at 219 posts.
The 'Uncategorized' category peaked at 996 posts.
10 tags have survived all 17 years: Math, Python, Number theory, Probability, RNG, Productivity, Integration, Mathematica, Unicode, Numerical analysis.
Gauss appears in 16 post titles. Euler in 10. Riemann in 7. The mathematician hierarchy extends to headlines.
'How' questions (54) outnumber 'Why' questions (34) in titles.

242 post titles contain numbers — dates, constants, dimensions — mathematical specificity starts at the headline.

232 posts are under 50 words — quick links, short observations, proof that not every thought needs an essay.
59 posts hit the 1000-1500 word range — the length of a proper technical essay, rare but not extinct.
Friday (561) and Saturday (555) are the quiet days. Tuesday (1,003) is the busiest — blogging as weekday work.
October leads with 480 posts. May trails at 394.
2018 saw a 45% jump from 184 to 266 posts.
2025 is a comeback year: 343 posts so far after 248 in 2024.

Sunday (466 posts) versus Tuesday (1,003 posts).
The blog started in 2008 with 410 posts—then never matched that pace until 2023's 395.

72 posts have 'theorem' in the title. 79 have 'approximation'. Pure math meets practical computation.
